newsitem.title: USA: Late rally boosted emerging market debts in U.S..
newsitem.headline: Late rally boosted emerging market debts in U.S..

text.p: A surge of late buying inspired by the strength in U.S. Treasuries lifted prices of emerging market bonds, traders said.
Spreads over Treasuries narrowed for most issues, led by a reduction of about 30 basis points for Venezuela papers, they said.
The volume was light because of the May Day holiday in many nations, traders said.
"People are changing their minds a little bit, that we are moving into a bull market and some people don't want to miss that and want to position a bid into that," one trader said.
But some other traders were more circumspect.
"It's very quiet. Nobody knows what's going to happen with the U.S. budget, and everybody's waiting for tomorrow's (payrolls) number," another one trader said.

The U.S. April employment data are scheduled for release at 830 EDT/1230 GMT. Analysts, on average, expected a rise of 211,000 in the non-farm payrolls and the unemployment rate holding steady at 5.2 percent.
Venezuela pars jumped a whopping 1-1/8 to 73-1/2 bid despite the recent announcement of a 44-percent increase in the official minimum wage.

"Probably the market has anticipated some of this negative news and has over-reacted in the sense that DCBs went to a spread level of 500 basis points over," said Kurt Schmid, head of proprietary trading at SBC Warburg.
Venezuela Bradys have underperformed the market until the latest bounce, which Schmidt thought was "more than justified" by the country's relatively good credit.
Argentina built on its recent upward momentum, with Par bonds rising 1-1/8 to 66-1/4 bid. FRBs gained 1/2 to 92-1/4.
Brazil and Mexico lagged among major Latins. Brazil C, rose 1/2 to 76-1/4 bid.
Mexico Pars and Mexico Discount each added 1/4 to bid 72-3/4 and 88-3/4 respectively.
